etymologies: Old English tǣsan (in tease (sense 2 of the verb)), of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch teezen and German dialect zeisen, also to teasel. Sense 1 is a development of the earlier and more serious ‘irritate by annoying actions’ (early 17th century), a figurative use of the word's original sense

definitions: make fun of or attempt to provoke (a person or animal) in a playful way

examples.text: Brenda teased her father about the powerboat that he bought but seldom used
“Think you're clever, don't you?” she teased

shortDefinitions: make fun of or attempt to provoke person or animal in playful way

definitions: tempt (someone) sexually with no intention of satisfying the desire aroused

examples.text: she had thrown herself at him and teased him

shortDefinitions: tempt someone sexually with no intention of satisfying desire aroused

definitions: gently pull or comb (tangled wool, hair, etc.) into separate strands

examples.text: she was teasing out the curls into her usual hairstyle

shortDefinitions: gently pull or comb (tangled wool, hair, etc.) into separate strands

definitions: comb (hair) in the reverse direction of its natural growth in order to make it appear fuller

examples.text: her hair is teased into spikes

shortDefinitions: backcomb hair in order to make it appear fuller

definitions: comb (the surface of woven cloth) to raise a nap.
shortDefinitions: comb surface of woven cloth to raise nap
